project_metadata.paper_title: Validating predictions of burial mounds with field data: the promise and reality of machine learning
project_metadata.research_context: Testing efficacy of pre-trained CNN with transfer learning for detecting burial mounds in IKONOS satellite imagery from Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria. Validates model predictions against field survey data to assess real-world performance versus self-reported metrics.

evidence.evidence_text: Model performance metrics showing high false positive and negative rates
evidence.verbatim_quote: tile-based false negative rates were 95–96%, false positive rates were 87–95% of tagged tiles, while true positives were only 5–13%
Development of the model, meanwhile, required approximately 135 person-hours of work

evidence.evidence_text: First model F1 score and detection rate
evidence.verbatim_quote: Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87), validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features with other phenomena. Tiles where the model predicted a mound with >60% probability contained a mound only 12.8% of the time

Despite increased effort in the selection of training data, the second run of the model reported a lower F1 score (0.62) and at >60% probability produced even more false positives (94.8%) and false negatives (96.2%). This run found only 21 mounds (2.7%)
Survey registered 773 burial mounds – whose presence was confirmed by personal inspection
These rounded, conical piles of earth and stones vary in diameter from 10 m to 100 m and <1 m to >20 m in height
Correct classification of linear road features with a pre-trained model required 1,250 h to digitise and annotate training datasets
the model flagged parts of the reservoir as a mound with >60% probability, despite the homogeneous water surface, bringing the question 'what is the CNN actually detecting?' to the fore

only 19 out of 148 tiles (12.8%) tagged by the model with at least a 60% chance of having a mound actually contained one... The 19 true-positive tiles contained 38 mounds (1–9 mounds per tile), out of 773 in the study area (4.9%)
Verschoof-van der Vaart et al. report that their models never reached the performance of crowdsourcing using volunteers (again, mostly due to its false positives)
The satellite imagery used in this study consists of two IKONOS scenes covering 600 sq km delivered in geoTIFF format
Our team included two digital archaeologists, a machine-learning specialist with experience applying ML approaches to cultural heritage data, and a junior developer who wrote much of the code
44 abstracts (63%) fail to mention any negative aspects of AI/ML approaches at all... Only 15 papers include specific or sustained critiques of ML approaches

Data processing and analysis was performed using R and Python and the scripts are available in public repositories: (1) Training data preparation and CNN prediction validation can be found in https://github.com/adivea/cnn-testing (2) 2021 CNN classifier training... https://github.com/centre-for-humanities-computing/burial-mounds (3) 2022 CNN classifier... https://github.com/centre-for-humanities-computing/MoundDetection
estimates range between 8,000 – 19,000 surviving today, of perhaps 50,000 originally constructed
The ratio of positive to negative training data was approximately 1:2 (32%–68%)

claims.claim_text: Self-reported ML success metrics are misleadingly high when not validated against field data
claims.verbatim_quote: Validation of results against field data showed that self-reported success rates were misleadingly high, and that the model was misidentifying most features

claims.claim_text: External validation with field data is essential for CNN archaeological prospection
claims.verbatim_quote: The model has detected incidental features rather than the mounds themselves, making external validation with field data an essential part of CNN workflows

claims.claim_text: ML approaches require significant time, expertise, and resources
claims.verbatim_quote: We further seek to raise awareness among researchers of the time, effort, expertise and resources necessary to implement ML successfully

claims.claim_text: Pre-trained CNN detects incidental background features rather than target archaeological features
claims.verbatim_quote: Models have been observed to predict class membership based on incidental background features in the periphery of the tiles that happen to accompany the target phenomenon in the centre

claims.claim_text: More selective training data unexpectedly led to worse model performance
claims.verbatim_quote: Counterintuitively, the model provided with training data selected for highly visible mounds (rather than all mounds) performed worse

claims.claim_text: The study had adequate training data (773 mounds) and high-resolution imagery
claims.verbatim_quote: We had at our disposal high-resolution, multispectral satellite imagery and a dataset of some 773 mounds registered during pedestrian survey

claims.claim_text: Pre-trained CNN limitations relate to varied feature sizes in heterogeneous landscapes
claims.verbatim_quote: Our attempt to deploy a pre-trained CNN demonstrates the limitations of this approach when it is used to detect varied features of different sizes within a heterogeneous landscape that contains confounding natural and modern features

claims.claim_text: Manual approaches (expert inspection or crowdsourcing) may outperform ML for feature detection
claims.verbatim_quote: the degree of manual intervention required... is so significant that it raises the question of whether it would be more efficient to identify all of the mounds manually

claims.claim_text: ML archaeology literature is overwhelmingly positive, reflecting publication bias
claims.verbatim_quote: The literature itself, however, is overwhelmingly positive, reflecting some combination of publication bias and a rhetoric of unconditional success

claims.claim_text: The study provides reproducibility infrastructure through public code repositories
claims.verbatim_quote: Data processing and analysis was performed using R and Python and the scripts are available in public repositories

claims.claim_text: Bulgarian burial mounds are endangered heritage requiring monitoring
claims.verbatim_quote: Despite the large number of burial mounds, they are endangered. Development in Bulgaria destroys dozens of mounds annually

claims.claim_text: This paper serves as a cautionary tale for potential ML adopters
claims.verbatim_quote: This paper presents the failure of a good-faith attempt to utilise these approaches as a counterbalance and cautionary tale to potential adopters of the technology

claims.claim_text: Volume of training data does not compensate for lack of curation
claims.verbatim_quote: We believed that the volume of training data would offset other shortcomings

claims.claim_text: Transfer learning promises may not hold for archaeological feature detection
claims.verbatim_quote: Transfer learning based on pre-trained models is sometimes proposed as solution to the problem of limited training data... Use of a pre-trained CNN potentially obviates the need to have large, high-quality, and representative datasets

claims.claim_text: Improving model performance would require substantial additional resources
claims.verbatim_quote: To overcome these challenges we would need to invest much more time, effort, and computing resources into additional steps

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Standard ML metrics (F1, accuracy) do not adequately capture real-world archaeological utility
trigger_text: Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87)
Validation of results against field data showed that self-reported success rates were misleadingly high
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper contrasts good self-reported metrics with poor field validation, implying standard metrics are insufficient for assessing archaeological utility.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Human visual interpretation expertise does not straightforwardly transfer to CNN capabilities
trigger_text: We also brought with us from manual inspection of satellite imagery the preconception that burial mounds were relatively easy to recognise in imagery
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Authors assumed CNN would perform like human experts at visual feature recognition, revealing unstated assumption about skill transferability.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Data quantity cannot substitute for data quality in ML training
trigger_text: We believed that the volume of training data would offset other shortcomings
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Authors explicitly acknowledge this failed assumption, bridging methodological choice to outcome.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Cost-effectiveness is an appropriate criterion for choosing between ML and manual methods
trigger_text: the return on additional time spent developing the ML approach diminishes rapidly, since we are already approaching a threshold where training student volunteers to identify mounds would be more efficient
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper frames method selection as efficiency decision, implying this is the primary criterion for method choice.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Publication bias systematically misrepresents ML performance in archaeological applications
trigger_text: The literature itself, however, is overwhelmingly positive
the relevant literature underreports failures, challenges, and limitations
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper argues its negative results are underrepresented, implying systematic bias in published literature.

research_designs.design_text: Validation study comparing CNN predictions to field-verified ground truth
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We set out to detect burial mounds in satellite imagery from a diverse landscape in Central Bulgaria using a pre-trained Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)... Results were assessed using field data
research_designs.rationale: Test whether pre-trained CNN can effectively detect archaeological features when validated against independent field data

research_designs.design_text: Two-run experimental comparison of training data selection strategies
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We employed a pre-trained CNN model with a low-touch approach to additional training, running the model twice using different collections of target features for training
research_designs.rationale: Test whether curated training data (visible mounds only) improves performance over inclusive data (all mounds)

research_designs.design_text: Transfer learning approach with minimal additional training
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We developed a pre-trained CNN that was further trained using two datasets
research_designs.rationale: Test transfer learning claims about reducing training data requirements

research_designs.design_text: Case study of Kazanlak Valley as representative heterogeneous archaeological landscape
research_designs.verbatim_quote: This paper offers a cautionary tale about the challenges, limitations, and demands of ML applied to archaeological prospection. We set out to detect burial mounds in the Kazanlak Valley
research_designs.rationale: Test ML in challenging but representative real-world conditions

methods.method_text: Pedestrian field survey for ground truth data collection
methods.verbatim_quote: Between 2009 and 2011, TRAP conducted pedestrian survey of 41.5 sq km of the Kazanlak Valley... Survey registered 773 burial mounds

methods.method_text: CNN transfer learning with pre-trained ResNet model
methods.verbatim_quote: A ResNet-18 model pre-trained with ImageNet data was modified for binary classification
the model split the 600 sq km geoTIFF into non-overlapping 150 × 150 pixel tiles rather than analyse the mosaiced image via a moving window
We verified mound predictions using points marking ground-truthed mounds in the 85 sq km section of the satellite image that had been systematically surveyed

methods.method_text: Training data preparation with MOUND/NOT MOUND cutouts
methods.verbatim_quote: We created two training datasets from the IKONOS mosaic: one from known burial mound locations and one from non-mound locations. The training image 'cutouts' in both cases are 150 × 150 pixel tiles

protocols.protocol_text: Training cutout generation from satellite imagery
protocols.verbatim_quote: Mound points taken during fieldwork were used as centroids for the generation of 150 × 150 m square polygons (150 × 150 pixels at 1 m resolution), which were clipped from the IKONOS imagery
Setting an identification threshold at 60% probability

protocols.protocol_text: First run training data selection (all mounds)
protocols.verbatim_quote: In the 2021 run of the model, we used all 773 cutouts for training regardless of what was visible in the satellite image

protocols.protocol_text: Second run training data selection (visible mounds only)
protocols.verbatim_quote: In the 2022 run, we selected 249 cutouts where a mound was discernible with the naked eye
All of the training images were augmented using vertical and horizontal flip and random rotation

parameters.augmentation: vertical flip, horizontal flip, random rotation

computational_environment.details: UCloud HPC system; R and Python; TensorFlow 2
